questions.text: A 22-Year-old primigravida is admitted due to pain in the abdomen. On conducting per abdomen examination she is found to have a longitudinal lie with the cephalic presentation, the head is not engaged. On PV examination, you feel the face as the presenting part. Your senior asked you to name the arbitrary bony fixed point on this presenting part.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mentum The term which is described in the given question is referred to as denominator.

Highyeild:

It is referred to as an arbitrary bony fixed point on the presenting part . Hence in face presentation, the denominator is the mentum(chin).

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Sacrum is the denominator in breech presentation. Option: B. Frontal eminence is the denominator in brow Option: C. Occiput is the denominator in vertex presentation.

questions.text: A 23-Year-old primigravida is admitted at 41 weeks of POG with abdominal pain for 4 hours, which has increased in intensity and duration. On PV examination following findings are noted: Cervix – 3cm dilated, 20% effaced, membranes intact. P/A examination reveals - regular rhythmic uterine contractions 2/10 min of 30 seconds duration. The JR told you that the patient is in the first stage of labour. You try to remember what you have studied regarding various pressures observed at different stages. The pressure corresponding to the first stage of labour is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

50 mm of Hg The intrauterine pressure during the first stage of labour is 40 - 50 mm of Hg.

Highyeild:

Contractions are predominant over the Rate of spread: 2cm/sec depolarizing the whole organ within 15 seconds. Throughout pregnancy, a pregnant female experiences painless contractions: Braxton hicks contractions.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option C : The intrauterine pressure during the second stage of labour is 100 to 120 mm of Hg. Option A: At 15 mm of Hg, the cervix dilates and contractions are painful. Option B: At 10 mm of Hg, uterine contractions are palpable.

Extraedge:

Adequate Uterine Contractions: 3 contractions in 10 minutes each lasting for 45 seconds and causing pressure of 65-75mmHg or 220 MV unit.

questions.text: A 30-Year-old G2P1 female came to the hospital at 42 weeks of gestation. She is concerned as she is getting labour pains. The doctor after checking her decides to induction. 2 hours after induction, CTG recordings state 6 contractions/ 10 minutes of duration 40 seconds. Other findings include fetal heart rate - 140 bpm and early decelerations. What should be the next best step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Do C-section as there is early deceleration

options.label: C
options.text: More contractions are required for normal labour, hence wait for contractions to progress

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sublingual nifedipine The given clinical scenario suggests tachysystole which is referred to as more than 5 contractions per 10 minutes . It can occur in both spontaneous and induced labour. The next best step among the given options will be sublingual nifedipine as it will relax the uterus and also help prevent fetal distress due to inadequate contractions.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A: We do not need to do a C-section as once tachysystole is controlled then the patient can be allowed to proceed for NVD provided no contraindications are already present. Option B : Continuous CTG monitoring alone is not helpful as active intervention is needed to stop the excess intrauterine contraction. CTG monitoring is important but is an adjunct to active management. Option C: Contractions are already more, hence we should give either sublingual nifedipine or s/c terbutaline to relax the uterus. Hence this option is wrong.

Extraedge:

When tachysystole causes fetal distress it is called hyperstimulation.

questions.text: A G2P1L1A0 30 -Year-old, with current twin pregnancy, is in labour with the first twin as cephalic presentation. The patient wants a normal vaginal delivery. Which among the following is the presentation of the other twin that will require an internal podalic version to make it breech followed by breech extraction?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

D In the given question, image D represents a transverse lie which requires an internal podalic version in case present in the second twin.

Highyeild:

After IPV, the presentation is converted into breech and breech extraction can be done. If the first twin is a transverse lie, then always do a C-section .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A : Longitudinal lie- cephalic presentation. Option B: Longitudinal lie- breech presentation. Option C: Oblique lie.

questions.text: All the following is true wrt the ‘power component’ of labour except

options.label: A
options.text: The pacemaker is located in the tubal ostia from where the waves of contraction start and progress downwards

options.label: C
options.text: Intra-amniotic pressure rises beyond 20 mm Hg during contractions

options.label: D
options.text: The lower segment of the uterus contracts more strongly and for a longer time than the upper part

questions.correct_answer: D. The lower segment of the uterus contracts more strongly and for a longer time than the upper part
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The lower segment of the uterus contracts more strongly and for a longer time than the upper part The lower segment of the uterus contracts more strongly and for a longer time than the upper part because there is a fundal predominance of the contractions, the contractions are more in intensity in the upper segment.

Highyeild:

Contractions are predominant over the Rate of spread: 2cm/sec depolarizing the whole organ within 15 seconds. Throughout pregnancy, a pregnant female experiences painless contractions: Braxton hicks contractions.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The pacemaker is located in the tubal ostia from where the waves of contraction start and progress downwards. The right pacemaker dominates the left one. Option: B. There is fundal dominance of the contractions. Contraction spread throughout the uterus in a fundo cervical progression at a rate of 2 cm/sec depolarising the whole organ within 15 sec. Option: C. Intra - amniotic pressure rises beyond 20 mm Hg during contractions.

Extraedge:

Contractions begin at 10mmHg Contractions are painful at 15mmHg Cervix dilates at 15mmHg Fundus cannot be indented at 40mmHg The first stage of labour 40-50mmHg The second stage of labour 100-120mmHg

questions.text: The commonest cause of non-engagement at term, in primi is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CPD Engagement is said to occur when the greatest transverse diameter of the presenting part, has passed through the pelvic inlet. In all cephalic presentations, the greatest transverse diameter is always biparietal. Engagement occurs in multipara with the commencement of labour in the late Ist stage after rupturing of membranes and in nullipara during the last few weeks of pregnancy, e. ≈ 38 weeks. In primi, the most common cause of non-engagement at term is the deflexed head or occipitoposterior position followed by cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD). Since deflexed head or occipitoposterior is not given an option, we will go for CPD as the answer.

Highyeild:

Causes of non-engagement of the head at term: Deflexed head bringing the larger diameter to engage. Cephalopelvic Disproportion or big head or a combination of both. Poor formation or yielding of the lower uterine segment prevents the head from sinking into the pelvis. Hydrocephalus Placenta previa Pelvic tumours - ovarian or fibroid High pelvic inclination Functional — when no cause can be detected (20%).

questions.text: During the descent of the passenger, one of the movements which occur in the passage is internal rotation. Which of the following statement is not true regarding assisting in the given movement:

options.label: A
options.text: The slope of the pelvic floor

questions.correct_answer: D. Tone of the abdominal muscles
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tone of the abdominal muscles The tone of the abdominal muscles: it does not help in internal rotation.

Highyeild:

8 cardinal movements of the head in normal labour: Engagement Descent Flexion Internal Rotation Crowning Extension Restitution External Rotation

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A. The slope of the pelvic floor: Two halves of levator ani fibres run backwards and toward the midline. Thus, during each contraction, the head, occiput in particular, in a well-flexed position, stretches the levator ani, particularly that half which is in relation to the occiput. After the contraction passes off, elastic recoil of the levator ani occurs bringing the occiput forward toward the midline . The process is repeated until the occiput is placed anteriorly. This is called rotation by the law of the pelvic floor (Hart’s rule). Option B. Law of unequal flexibility: The internal rotation is primarily due to inequalities in the flexibility of the component parts of the fetus. Option C. Pelvic shape: Forward inclination of the side walls of the cavity, narrow bispinous diameter and long anteroposterior diameter of the outlet result in putting the long axis of the head to accommodate the maximum available diameter. Hence it helps in internal rotation.

Extraedge:

If the engagement has occurred: station O i.e. at the level of the ischial spine. 1/5th head is palpable per abdomen.

questions.text: During your obstetric practical examination, the external examiner asked you to perform the Leopold maneuver in which you determine the degree of descent and also whether the head has been engaged or not. Which of the following image represents the above-described maneuver?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

d In the given question from the above description, it is clear that the maneuver described is the Leopold fourth maneuver . In this, the examiner faces the patient's feet and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. If the fingers converge, then engagement has not been said to occur and vice versa if fingers diverge.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. a: First maneuver or the fundal grip which tells about the fetal lie and the presentation. Option: C. b: The second Leopold maneuver or the lateral grip . It helps define the presenting part and position. Option: D. c: It represents the third grip – which is important for confirmation of the fetal position.

questions.text: Identify the given position of the fetus in the pelvis in the given image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right occiput posterior In the given image, the posterior fontanelle is facing towards the sacrum (occiput posterior) on the right side (side decided according to our side being opposite that of the patient). Hence it is the right occiput posterior.

Highyeild:

MC position of the fetus LOT MC position of the fetus during labour LOT MC position during late labour LOA MC occipitoanterior position LOA MC occipitoposterior position ROP

questions.text: Uterine contractions during labour are unique among the physiological muscular contraction as they are painful. Which of the following are assumed to be the cause of it? Hypoxia of the contracted myometrium. Compression of the nerve ganglia in the cervix and lower uterine segments by contracted interlocking muscle bundles. Cervical stretching during dilation Stretching of peritoneum overlying the fundus. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A, B, C, D Various hypotheses have been given for the uterine contraction to be painful.

Random:

Explanation For other Options:- Option: A. Hypoxia of the contracted myometrium. Option: B. Compression of the nerve ganglia in the cervix and lower uterine segments by contracted interlocking muscle bundles. It is an especially attractive hypothesis. Option: C. Cervical stretching during dilation. Option: D. Stretching of peritoneum overlying the fundus. Hence all options are correct.

questions.text: Which of the following factors are responsible for the onset of labour?

options.label: C
options.text: Prostaglandins from amnion, chorion, decidual cells, and myometrium

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Various factors including biochemical, endocrine and mechanical plays an important role in the onset of labour.

Highyeild:

Other important factors can be estrogen and progesterone which promotes the release of oxytocin from the posterior pituitary and also increases myometrial receptors of PGs and oxytocin in the uterus.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Uterine distension: Uterine stretch increases gap junction proteins, receptors for oxytocin and specific contraction-associated proteins (CAPs). Option: B. Fetoplacental contribution: It plays a very important role as fetal ACTH acts on fetal adrenal glands which leads to increased cortisol secretion and in turn increases the production of estrogen and progesterone from the placenta. Option: C. Prostaglandins from amnion, chorion, decidual cells, and myometrium. Prostaglandins enhance gap junction (the intermembranous gap between two cells through which stimulus flows) formation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true wrt to the contractile system of the myometrium during labour:

options.label: A
options.text: Structural unit of a myometrial cell is myofibril which contains the proteins—actin and myosin.

options.label: B
options.text: The key process in actin-myosin interaction is myosin light chain dephosphorylation.

options.label: C
options.text: Progesterone and cAMP promote calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria.

options.label: D
options.text: Uterine muscles have two types of adrenergic receptors out of which α receptors on stimulation produce a decrease in cyclic AMP and uterine relaxation.

questions.correct_answer: A. Structural unit of a myometrial cell is myofibril which contains the proteins—actin and myosin.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Structural unit of a myometrial cell is myofibril which contains the proteins—actin and myosin.

Highyeild:

The following is the mechanism of myometrium contraction: Intracellular Ca++ → calmodulin Ca++ → MLCK → phosphorylated myosin + actin → myometrial contraction. Contractions are predominant over the fundus. Rate of spread: 2cm/sec depolarizing the whole organ within 15 seconds. Throughout pregnancy, a pregnant female experiences painless contractions: Braxton hicks contractions.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. The key process in actin-myosin interaction is myosin light chain dephosphorylation is wrong, as MLC phosphorylation and not dephosphorylation. Option: C. Progesterone and cAMP promote calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria are wrong as they promote storage. PGF2α, E2 and oxytocin on the other hand stimulate its release. Option: D. Uterine α receptors on stimulation produce a decrease in cyclic AMP and uterine contraction while β receptors have just the opposite effect.
